Hey. Emanuel Mayberg. Hello. And Jason

good. Thanks for bearing with us if it
sounds weird. Yeah, please uh bear with

Jason, you've just published a couple of

based on something that went viral and
we'll all get into that and you got a
ton more tons more information about it
and it actually sort of symbolizes a lot
that's happening in the media industry
and with AI as well. But the first
story, the headline was Chicago Sun
Times prints AI generated summer reading
list with books that don't exist. So,
this thing starts blowing up on social
media definitely Tuesday, potentially
Monday as well. Correct me if I'm wrong.
What was this thing that was blowing up
on the face of it? Yeah. So, the Chicago
Sun Times is a newspaper in Chicago
that's been around for a long time.
There's a Chicago Tribune and then the
Chicago Sun Times is like the second
newspaper in Chicago and it it still
exists. But basically, they ran
uh this special insert in their Sunday
paper this past Sunday called uh heat
index um your guide to the best summer.
And this was a 64 page special section
of the newspaper that was like what you
should be doing this summer. We can talk
more about like what was in it. Yeah. It
was just like a year. Yeah. like have
fun in the sun, like here's books you
can read over the summer, here's things
that you can do, so on and so forth. Um,
and in that they had an article called
summer reading list for
2025. And in that reading list, they
suggested a bunch of books that do not

like Isabella Yende, um, you know, Andy

they suggested reading the last
algorithm by Andy Weir. And then the

the blurb in the article says quote this
time the story follows a programmer who
discovers that an AI system has
developed consciousness and has been
secretly influencing global events for
years. Uh this book doesn't exist like
Andy Weir has not written this book.
Isabella Yende did not write a book

noticed by actually a bookt talker on
threads of all places and then it got

was clearly AI generated in some way.
Yeah. And I guess that's what makes it a
little bit different because obviously

readers of the site will know there's

AI generated articles or press releases
or whatever. Um, but this is different

sometimes is basically like an
institution or at least an incredibly

physically printed AI slop or I suppose

and I bought a digital copy of the

journalism is that I I first worked as
an intern at Washingtonian magazine
which is a magazine in Washington DC and
my job was to fact check articles like
this or like se sections like this. I
mean, there's all sorts of things, but
basically like every local newspaper or
magazine does this thing where they're
like, "Summer is coming up. Here are

this by like having a bunch of interns.
Go to the websites of every music venue

that's how I It used to be that's how I
did it. And very specifically, it will
be like go see this concert at this
Chicago music venue. Like that that's
what this section probably should have
been. And something that I noticed right

they they didn't mention Chicago even
one time in the entire section. Uh the
entire section starts off with like a
hundred things to do on your summer
bucket list. And it's like go snorkeling
in the crystal clear waters near your

Yeah, Lake Michigan is not crystal
clear. I don't know if you've ever
checked it out. Um, and the Chicago

but it's not crystal clear snorkeling
waters. Uh, and so I was just like, this
is
not like at the very least is incredibly
incredibly generic. Uh, and then I I saw
that, you know, none of these books

common when you did this as well, like
when you did this work, was would the
intern's name be on there or was it also
no by line? Well, it was funny. Uh,
often it was not on there because it
would just be like a calendar listing.
So, it was like it wouldn't say like
Jason Kevler compiled this list of
concerts. Uh, usually our name would be

that like we worked at the magazine and
then to get a by line you had to
actually like write something. So you

sometimes you would get your like
initials in there and sometimes you
would get uh your actual name. And it
was actually like a big to-do whether

noticed that like every single byelined

Marco Buskaglia. Like it was it was all
done by one person. And so I emailed

immediately responded to me and was
like, "I did use AI and I'm very sorry

embarrassed." Uh he said and then he
called me or I called him rather. He
gave me his phone number and I called

background at times, but always check
out the material first. This time I did
not and I can't believe I missed it
because it's so obvious. No excuses on
me 100% and I'm completely embarrassed."
Uh and then I talked to him on the phone
and he sort of reiterated the same

put it into their newspapers because
it's cheaper to do that than it is to

like a this is not a new thing. Like
this has been going on forever.
Like newspapers will not have their I

there yeah they'll buy a cross word

The fact that somebody at the paper was
like we just straight up said we don't

And I definitely got edits, you know,

possibly
